quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 12: Unit 12 Quiz 10
quiz.subtitle: 12.10: Crystal Field Theory
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: d-orbital splitting, spectrochemical series, and color

questions.question: Crystal Field Theory (CFT) explains the properties of transition metal complexes by considering:
options: Electrostatic repulsions between ligand lone pairs and metal d-electrons.
Covalent sharing of electrons in sigma and pi bonds.
The overlap of s and p orbitals of the metal.
The gravitational attraction between the nucleus and ligands.
questions.explanation: CFT treats ligands as point charges. The approach of these charges causes the five degenerate d-orbitals to split into different energy levels due to repulsion.

questions.question: In an octahedral crystal field, which d-orbitals are raised highest in energy?
options: All five d-orbitals are raised equally.
questions.explanation: In an octahedral field, ligands approach along the axes. The $d_{x^{2}-y^{2}}$ and $d_{z^{2}}$ orbitals (the $e_{g}$ set) point directly at the ligands and experience maximum repulsion.

questions.question: The energy difference between the $t_{2g}$ and $e_{g}$ orbital sets is symbolized by:
questions.explanation: $Δ_{o}$ represents the crystal field splitting energy for an octahedral complex.

questions.question: Which of the following ligands is considered a 'strong-field' ligand according to the spectrochemical series?
questions.explanation: Cyanide ($CN^{-}$) and Carbon monoxide ($CO$) cause the largest splitting ($Δ$), whereas halides like $I^{-}$ and $Br^{-}$ cause the smallest.

questions.question: A 'low-spin' octahedral complex occurs when:
options: The splitting energy ($Δ_{o}$) is greater than the pairing energy ($P$).
The splitting energy ($Δ_{o}$) is less than the pairing energy ($P$).
The temperature of the solution is absolute zero.
questions.explanation: If the 'gap' is large (strong field), electrons will pair up in the lower energy $t_{2g}$ orbitals rather than jumping to the higher $e_{g}$ orbitals.

questions.question: Why are many transition metal complexes brightly colored?
options: Electrons absorb light to move from the lower d-orbitals to higher d-orbitals.
The metal nucleus emits visible light during radioactive decay.
Ligands reflect all wavelengths of light except for one.
The complex ions vibrate at the frequency of visible light.
questions.explanation: This is known as a d-d transition. The energy of the absorbed photon corresponds to the crystal field splitting energy ($Δ$).

questions.question: If a complex absorbs orange light (~600 nm), what color will it likely appear to the human eye?
questions.explanation: The perceived color is the complement of the absorbed color. Blue is the complement of orange on the color wheel.

questions.question: Tetrahedral complexes are almost always 'high-spin' because:
options: The crystal field splitting ($Δ_{t}$) is much smaller than in octahedral fields.
Tetrahedral complexes only form with strong-field ligands.
They have more d-electrons than octahedral complexes.
The pairing energy is effectively zero.
questions.explanation: $Δ_{t}$ is roughly $4/9$ the size of $Δ_{o}$. Because the gap is so small, the pairing energy usually exceeds the splitting energy.

questions.question: Which of the following ions would be colorless in aqueous solution?
questions.explanation: $Zn^{2+}$ has a $d^{10}$ configuration. Since the d-orbitals are completely full, no d-d transitions are possible.

questions.question: How does the oxidation state of the metal affect the splitting energy?
options: Oxidation state has no effect on $Δ$.
questions.explanation: A higher positive charge pulls ligands closer to the metal, increasing the electrostatic repulsion and thus the splitting of the d-orbitals.

scoreMessages.90: Brilliant! You have mastered the complexities of Crystal Field Theory.
scoreMessages.70: Good job. You understand how d-orbital splitting leads to color and magnetism.
scoreMessages.50: Satisfactory. Review the difference between high-spin and low-spin configurations.
scoreMessages.0: Focus on the spectrochemical series and the definition of $Δ$.
